title: Coronavirus reopening: Map of when US states are ending lockdown
headline: Map of COVID-19 case trends, reopening status and mobility
deck: Across the United States, governors are rolling out a patchwork of constantly evolving plans to relax social distancing restrictions. At the height of restrictions in late March and early April, more than 310 million Americans were under directives ranging from “shelter in place” to “stay at home.” The orders varied by state, county and even city. Health officials warn that easing restrictions too soon could bring new outbreaks, but many states have forged ahead.
meta_description: USA TODAY is tracking when all 50 states plan to reopen and end lockdown.
share_text: Coronavirus reopening: Map of when US states are ending lockdown

states.eased_buckets: T, B, R, F, C, E, S
states.copy: All Alabama public schools are set to reopen on time unless local boards or the governor chooses otherwise, State Superintendent Eric Mackey announced. A safer at home order is in place until at least July 3. Casinos reopened June 8. On May 23, large entertainment venues, athletic activities, and school and child-care facilities were allowed to reopen with physical distancing guidelines and capacity limits. Gov. Kay Ivey loosened coronavirus restrictions May 11, allowing limited operations of restaurants, hair and nail salons, and gyms.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 9,063 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 6,905 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: H, C, R, F, E, T
states.copy: Life went back to the way it was "prior to the virus" on May 22, Gov. Mike Dunleavy announced. All businesses – including restaurants, bars, retail stores and gyms – will be allowed to open without any capacity restrictions and without needing to provide hand sanitizer or enforcing social distancing guidelines. Previously, Dunleavy and state officials had issued a number of health orders as a part of the phased Reopen Alaska Responsibly Plan. The final two phases will be carried out simultaneously on May 22.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 254 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 201 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: H, T, C, R, E, F, P, S
states.copy: Gov. Doug Ducey issued an executive order requiring bars, gyms, theaters and water parks to shut down June 29. The order follows mounting pressure to respond to ballooning COVID-19 numbers that followed his accelerated reopening plan, which he announced in May. Arizona schools will delay reopening for in-person classes this year until at least Aug. 17.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 25,226 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 24,164 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: H, F, E, R, T, S, C
states.copy: Nearly two weeks after moving into phase two, which allowed for two-thirds capacity in restaurants and other businesses, Gov. Asa Hutchinson said he's not ready to ease restrictions further as the state experiences a spike in coronavirus cases. Arkansas moved into phase two of reopening June 15, which increased capacity for venues, restaurants, gyms and other businesses. Nonessential school, schools and camp activities could resume. Arkansas reopened large indoor venues such as movie theaters, museums, and bowling alleys on May 18. Dental services could resume and restaurant dining rooms could reopen May 11.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is shrinking, with 3,977 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 4,013 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: H, S, T, C, P, E, R, F
states.copy: As California faces an explosion of new COVID-19 cases, Gov. Gavin Newsom ordered 19 counties — including Los Angeles, Orange and Santa Clara — to shut down businesses with indoor operations for three weeks. That includes theaters, wineries, museums and restaurants. Bars, gyms, stadium sports, schools, movie theaters and other entertainment businesses had reopened June 12. Newsom said May 26 that barbershops and hair salons could reopen in counties that have been cleared to move faster on lifting coronavirus restrictions.  Other businesses reopened statewide May 12.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 55,934 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 45,438 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: H, C, T, P, R, O
states.copy: Bars in Colorado can reopen after a relaxation of restrictions went into effect. Bar occupancy is now limited to 25% or 50 people, whichever is lower. Colorado Gov. Jared Polis on June 15 announced plans to further relax coronavirus restrictions and allow for more decisions on restrictions to be made by local health departments. The eased restrictions apply to summer camps, indoor and outdoor gatherings and other areas. Polis issued an executive order June 1 extending the coronavirus restrictions under the state's safer-at-home order while lifting restrictions on vulnerable residents and encouraging more Coloradans to get outdoors. Colorado restaurants and day camps are allowed to open in a limited capacity.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 2,172 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 1,872 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: T, R, E, O, C, E, F
states.copy: Gov. Ned Lamont said July 2 that he would pause the full-scale reopening of bars, which had been planned for mid-July. Public schools will reopen in the fall with safety measures, including mask-wearing and smaller class sizes. Phase two of reopening began June 17, allowing most businesses to reopen, including gyms, nail salons, libraries and others. Hotels, amusement parks and restaurants will have restrictions. Connecticut took its first steps toward a return to normalcy on May 20, as offices, retail stores, malls, restaurants (for outdoor dining), outdoor museums and zoos are now open.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is shrinking, with 563 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 652 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: R, C, T, P, G, F
states.copy: Phase two of reopening Washington D.C. began June 22, which allows for gatherings of up to 50 people, and for gyms, camps, museums, nonessential retail and indoor dining at restaurants to resume at limited capacity. The district's stay-at-home order was lifted May 29, commencing phase one of a four-phase approach for reopening businesses. Six stores, including four bookstores, were allowed to reopen May 18. On May 13, Mayor Muriel Bowser extended the District's stay-at-home order through June 8.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 289 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 231 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: T, C, R, G
states.copy: Delaware did not move into phase three of its economic reopening plan as scheduled on June 29, Gov. John Carney announced. Phase two of reopening began June 15, allowing private instruction and testing services, golf courses, as well as larger gatherings. Nail and hair salons and tatoo parlors could operate at 30% capacity starting June 8. Phase one of Gov. John Carney's reopening plan started June 1, allowing some establishments to reopen with strict requirements.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 800 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 751 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: B, O, H, T, C, F, E, R, S
states.copy: On June 26, the state's Department of Business and Professional Regulation announced it would suspend on-premise consumption of alcohol at bars statewide. Bars will still be able to serve drinks in to-go containers. Bars had reopened on June 1. The state lifted restrictions on restaurant and retail store capacity from 25% to 50% on May 18, as well as allowing the reopening of museums, libraries and gyms at 50% capacity. DeSantis said May 15 that people who are healthier are less likely to die from the coronavirus, which was part of his rationale to include gyms as the state expands the first phase of its reopening.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 63,612 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 55,088 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: F, C, T, R
states.copy: Starting June 16, restaurants in Georgia no longer needed to limit capacity. A shelter-in-place for elderly and compromised individuals ended June 12. Guidelines were released by the state's department of education to start reopening schools in the fall. Gov. Brian Kemp on May 12 announced plans to relax some restaurant restrictions and allow some summer camps to open but extend bar and nightclub closures through May. Kemp allowed businesses such as tattoo parlors, bowling alleys and hair and nail salons to reopen with restrictions in late April, a sweeping move that prompted national criticism. Restaurants and movie theaters have since been able to welcome customers back in on a limited basis, and a statewide shelter-at-home order has expired. Some malls reopened May 4, though things were far from normal with many businesses inside still shuttered and parking lots sparsely filled.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 19,018 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 16,614 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: B, H, T
states.copy: Starting August 1, travellers who test negative for the coronavirus 72 before arrival can avoid quarantine. Hawaii ended interisland travel quarantine June 16. Gov. David Ige extended mandatory quarantine for mainland and international travelers until August. Ige unveiled May 18 a four-phase reopening strategy for Hawaii’s economy with the state gradually allowing medium-risk businesses such as churches, gyms, museums, theaters, restaurants and hair salons to begin operations in June. Hawaii has been under a statewide stay-at-home order since the last week of March. Ige has relaxed some restrictions, including allowing shopping malls to reopen. In Maui, they did so May 11; in Oahu they reopened May 15. Beaches on Oahu opened on May 16.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 184 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 95 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: T, R, C, F, E
states.copy: Gov. Brad Little announced that the state will remain in phase four of its reopening process through at least July 10 after a nearly monthlong spike in COVID-19 cases. Phase four allows visits to senior living facilities and corrections facilities, and it lets nightclubs and sporting venues open with limited capacity. It is the last stage before full reopening.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 2,836 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 1,728 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: H, O, G, T, E, C
states.copy: Illinois entered phase four of reopening on June 26, allowing health care centers, schools, entertainment and other businesses to open with capacity restrictions. The state had been in phase three since May 29, which allowed additional businesses to open and gatherings of small groups. Chicago entered phase three June 3. Most businesses can reopen with capacity guidelines, gyms can open for private workouts and restaurants are open for delivery, pickup and drive through. Restaurants are also allowed to open outdoor seating in this phase with social distancing requirements still in place. Residents are directed to wear face coverings when outside and can resume outdoor recreational activities such as golf, boating and fishing as long as social distancing is practiced.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 6,690 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 5,448 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: H, G, T, R, F, E
states.copy: Gov. Eric Holcomb announced a new stage of reopening that began July 4. Stage 4.5 will temporarily pause increases in capacity at restaurants, bars and entertainment venues, among others. Indiana was supposed to enter the fifth and final stage of its reopening plan on that date. Under stage 4, retail stores and malls could operate at full capacity while restaurants worked at 75% capacity. Bars, nightclubs, movie theaters and bowling alleys could open at 50% capacity. Social gatherings of up to 250 people were allowed as well.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 3,188 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 2,732 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: H, R, T, E, C, F, G
states.copy: Iowa education officials released guidelines June 25 that will allow schools to reopen to normal activities without requirements that students and teachers wear face coverings, undergo temperature checks at the door, or observe social distancing in schools. Effective June 12, the 50% capacity limit in place for Iowa businesses was lifted. Swimming pools, fitness centers and personal care businesses are included. More reopenned June 1, including casinos, amusement parks, arcades and others. Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds loosened more restrictions on businesses and recreational activities May 26, as well as eased additional safeguards on bars and restaurants and limitations on gatherings of 10 people or more. She lifted mandated closures of barbershops, salons and massage therapy businesses statewide starting May 15.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 2,995 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 2,886 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: T, R, F, C, E, O, G
states.copy: Gov. Laura Kelly signed an executive order that mandates masks in public spaces statewide in order to deal with an upward trend in new coronavirus cases. On June 22, Kelly recommended communities remain in phase three of reopening. Under phase three, bars and nightclubs are allowed to reopen, operating at a capacity of no more than 50%. Personal services, such as beauty shops and nail salons, can have no more than 45 people within shops at a given time. Events, such as fairs, festivals, carnivals, parades and concerts, are allowed. Gyms and fitness centers are allowed in this phase to let members use showers and locker rooms.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 2,783 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 1,895 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: H, R, E, C, T, F, S
states.copy: Most businesses and attractions in the Bluegrass State have been allowed to reopen amid the coronavirus pandemic. Kentucky's public school students will be required to wear masks, have their temperatures checked and keep their distance from peers in order to safely return to class this fall, according to guidance released by Gov. Andy Beshear's administration. Houses of worship could reopen at 50% capacity starting June 10. State parks, libraries, museums and other areas reopened June 8. Gyms, bowling allies and some movie theaters reopened June 1. Hair and nail salons have reopened, as well as retail and restaurants at limited capacity. Kentucky's travel ban expired May 22, and restaurants can reopen their doors to in-person traffic at 33% capacity indoors and full capacity outdoors.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 2,166 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 1,462 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: T, R, C, F, E
states.copy: Gov. John Bel Edwards issued a 28-day order June 22 to keep the state in phase two of reopening rather than move to phase three as he had hoped. Phase two allows restaurants, malls, gyms, theaters, museums, bars and other businesses to open at 50% capacity. Bel Edwards signed Louisiana into phase two of reopening June 4.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 10,433 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 8,146 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: O, C, H, R, P, B, F
states.copy: Gov. Janet Mills will delay the July 1 reopening of bars, but they can continue serving outdoors. More venues in the state, including movie theaters, casinos and museums, can reopen as part of its third phase of reopening – with a 50-person cap and a checklist of requirements. More counties were able to reopen June 17, easing restrictions for gyms and personal care services, restaurants, bars and tasting rooms. Stage three of reopening is set to begin in July.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is shrinking, with 158 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 258 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: O, B, T, C, H, E, F, R
states.copy: Indoor dining, fitness centers, casinos, arcades and malls reopened June 12 with restrictions. Outdoor entertainment like mini golf can also reopen at 50% capacity. Gov. Larry Hogan lifted restrictions on nonessential businesses as Maryland entered phase two of its recovery plan on June 5. Personal care services can operate at 50% capacity. A stay-at-home order was lifted May 15 at 5 p.m. and was be replaced with a safer-at-home public health advisory.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 3,024 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 2,646 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: O, H, P, C, R, C, F
states.copy: State education officials released guidance on reopening schools this fall. Massachusetts entered into the second stage of phase two of reopening June 22. Indoor dining (with restrictions), nail salons and tattoo parlors can all reopen. Childcare and daycamps, outdoor recreation, retail, professional sports and other businesses can reopen with restrictions. Houses of worship are allowed to resume services if they can also follow social distancing guidance. Recreation also reopened, including parks, drive-in theaters, some athletic fields and courts, most fishing, hunting, and boating, outdoor gardens, zoos, and reserves.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 1,559 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 1,501 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: O, T, R, C, P
states.copy: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer closed indoor bar service in south and central Michigan, saying it's needed to control an increase in the spread of the coronavirus. A federal appeals court scuttled plans to reopen gyms on June 25, ruling to keep them shut indefinitely. Hair salons, barbershops and other personal service shops, such as nail salons, can reopen. Whitmer announced June 1 that she had lifted the state's stay-at-home order and that all Michigan bars and restaurants could reopen at 50% capacity June 8. Office work can also resume if work cannot be done remotely. Michigan manufacturing resumed May 11, with the auto plants scheduled to restart one week later, on May 18.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 3,385 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 2,689 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: O, T, H, G, E
states.copy: Museums will reopen June 29, and schools have created three separate contingency plans for reopening for the 2020-21 school year. Minnesota's third phase of reopening began June 10, allowing movie theaters, bowling alleys, gyms and pools to reopen. Restrictions were also loosened for bars and restaurants. Under phase two, outdoor seating at restaurants and limited capacity of salons and barbershops could resume. Casinos began reopening May 26, with some restrictions, and places of worship could reopen with limited capacity May 27. Retail stores and malls are allowed to reopen, but must do so at 50% capacity and must have plans to keep workers and customers safe. Religious gatherings can resume with a 10-person limit. Doctors, dentists and veterinarians started providing elective surgeries again on May 11 but were required to create a plan to keep patients and health care workers safe.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is shrinking, with 2,953 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 3,087 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: T, R, P, C, F, E
states.copy: Starting June 1, all businesses in Mississippi could reopen, with restrictions. The state's Department of Education released guidelines allowing schools to reopen in the fall. On May 19, Gov. Tate Reeves allowed churches to resume in-person services, with some restrictions. Casinos reopened May 21. Reeves allowed salons, barbershops and gyms to resume operations on May 11. He also extended his "Safer At Home" order, which allows for some restrictions to be lifted, for another two weeks. Restaurants and parks reopened May 7. Among other changes: up to 20 people will be allowed gather for outdoor activities, but gatherings are still limited to 10 people or less for indoor activities.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 4,821 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 4,254 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: R, T
states.copy: Missouri Gov. Mike Parson let his statewide social distancing order lapse June 9, leaving it to local governments to impose limits on public life amid the coronavirus outbreak. In areas without their own orders, the decision means social distancing requirements for restaurants and retailers will end and people will no longer be legally required to stay 6 feet apart from non-family members in public. Prohibitions on visiting long-term facilities like nursing homes will also be lifted. Missouri will fully reopen and enter Phase two of its “Show Me Strong Recovery” plan on June 16.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 3,774 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 2,999 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: T, R, S, E, F
states.copy: Montana entered into phase two of the states's reopening plan June 1. Gov. Steve Bullock said that restaurants, bars, breweries, distilleries and casinos can run at 75% of capacity. Gyms, indoor fitness classes, pools and hot tubs can operate at 75% of capacity. Bowling alleys can operate at decreased capacity with social distancing guidelines. Some Montana schools reopened May 7 when Gov. Gyms, theaters and some museums reopened May 15 with reduced capacity, social distancing and sanitizing requirements.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 383 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 280 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: R, C, S, F, E, G, P
states.copy: Several state park centers and restaurants will reopen July 1. All but four Nebraska counties entered the third phase of reopening June 22. Under phase three, full capacity at restaurants is allowed, spectators at youth sports can gather and all restrictions on elective surgeries will be lifted. Hall, Merrick, Hamilton and Dakota counties entered phase two on the same day. In those counties, restaurants are open for indoor dining, and bars are open with limited capacity. Gyms, salons, barber shops, massage therapy services, tattoo parlors and wedding and funeral reception venues could also reopen with restrictions. Gov. Pete Ricketts eased travel quarantine requirements June 1, and allowed non-contact sports to resume practicing. Ricketts loosened restrictions May 4 in most of the state.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 1,171 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 1,106 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: R, T, C, F, E, S
states.copy: Gov. Steve Sisolak will sign an emergency directive extending phase two of the state’s COVID-19 recovery plan through the end of July, according to a Monday news release from the governor’s office. Churches, salons, bars and gyms, all at limited capacity, were part of the state's second phase. Restaurants, retail stores, barbershops, hair salons and some brewpubs could resume limited operations on May 9.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 5,171 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 4,874 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: H, T, C, E, R, B, G, F
states.copy: Restaurants in New Hampshire can offer indoor dining starting June 22. Other close-contact businesses like nail salons and appointment-only personal training can resume as well. The state's stay-at-home order expired June 15, and many businesses can reopen, including gyms, pools, funeral homes and others. Gatherings will no longer be limited. Beaches and personal care services reopened June 1, with public health guidelines. Hair salons, barbershops, retail stores and drive-in movie theaters reopened May 11 with different requirements for the various industries. Dentists resumed some routine work starting May 11 as well.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is shrinking, with 151 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 184 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: O, P, T, F, C, S
states.copy: Gov. Phil Murphy said that after seeing a spike in coronavirus cases in states that have reopened indoor dining, he is postponing it indefinitely. Murphy said he does not anticipate allowing restaurants to resume indoor dining for weeks. Salons, pools and youth sports could reopen June 22. Most nonessential businesses reopened June 15 with 50% capacity restrictions when the state moved into phase two. Murphy signed an executive order May 19 allowing in-person sales at car, motorcycle and boat dealerships, along with bicycle shops, on May 20. New Jersey allowed retail stores to reopen for curbside pickup service only and nonessential construction to resume on May 18.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is shrinking, with 1,914 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 2,160 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: T, O, P, R
states.copy: New Mexico's coronavirus spread is trending upward, state health officials said at a press conference June 25, leading the state to put the next phase of reopenings on hold. Beginning June 12, New Mexico breweries were be permitted to resume outdoor patio seating at 50 percent of their fire code occupancy, and on June 15, that partial reopening was be extended to indoor seating as well. Effective June 1, New Mexico's emergency public health order was extended and amended to permit indoor dining, hair salons, gyms and shopping malls. Limited dine-in options began at residents May 27. Many nonessential retailers, pet groomers, state parks and golf courses resumed operations May 1 in a limited way under a new, modified state public health order, in effect through May 15. New Mexico "slight reopening" began May 16, but everyone is required to wear a face mask in public spaces and the stay-at-home order remains in effect.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 1,731 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 1,328 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: O, H, E, R, T, C, G
states.copy: Five regions of New York entered phase four June 26, allowing gatherings of 50 people and indoor religious gatherings at 33% capacity. New York City entered phase two of reopening June 11. Restaurants in these regions can offer indoor and outdoor service, and personal care services can resume. Summer day camps statewide can open on June 29. Gov. Andrew Cuomo said on May 18 that "New York State is ready and willing to partner with major sports teams that are interested in playing games safely, without fans." Cuomo also announced that New York reopened statewide certain low-risk businesses and recreational activities on May 15, including landscaping and gardening, outdoor low-risk recreational activities like tennis and drive-in movie theaters.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 4,559 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 4,539 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: T, E, C, R
states.copy: North Carolina will not move into the next phase of easing coronavirus restrictions after Gov. Roy Cooper moved to extend the current phase for another three weeks, through July 17, and to add a new requirement that face coverings be worn in most public spaces. Cooper vetoed another attempt by Republican legislators to accelerate the speed in which North Carolina commerce is being restored through his COVID-19 executive order. He also vetoed a bill containing help for bars and restaurants, saying legislation was the wrong way to reopen during uncertain times in which virus cases could spike. North Carolina moved on to phase 2 of a three-stage reopening plan May 22, but with more restrictions than expected. The safer-at-home order will be lifted, and restaurants, personal care, grooming and swimming pools can reopen at 50% capacity.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 11,440 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 10,744 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: T, C, R, F, E
states.copy: Several North Dakota counties are close to entering the fifth and final stage of reopening, which will allow businesses to operate normally. The state is currently in the fourth phase, or the "green" phase. Restaurants can open at 75% capacity. Banquets and weddings can have as many as 250 people and movie theaters can reopen at up to 65% capacity. Fitness centers can hold classes with social distancing.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 414 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 264 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: T, H, O, C, R, E
states.copy: Casinos, amusement parks and water parks could reopen June 19. Zoos, museums and more in the state could reopen starting June 10. Restrictions of public and club sports; adult and youth sports leagues; gyms and fitness centers were adjusted May 26. Gov. Mike DeWine announced that hair salons, barbershops and other personal care businesses would reopen on May 15. Restaurants and bars opened outdoor patios and spaces on May 15 and indoor seating resumed on May 21. Massage parlors, tattoo parlors and piercing businesses also reopened on May 15.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 7,165 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 6,515 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: C, H, E, R, F, T, S
states.copy: Movie theaters in Oklahoma have begun reopening and Gov. Kevin Stitt said June 26 he does not plan on closing businesses again as coronavirus cases begin to surge. Phase three of reopening began June 1. Businesses can resume at full capacity, and limited visitation can resume at hospitals at the discretion of facilities. Funeral homes, churches, nurseries, bars and nightclubs are among the businesses that opened under phase 2. State health officials have given strict directives for social distancing and disinfection, allowing restaurants to open dining rooms May 15 after being closed for six weeks. Movie theaters, churches and concert halls, gyms, salons and other businesses have all reopened. Social gatherings of 10 or more people are still forbidden.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 3,966 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 2,583 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: H, O, P, R, G, E
states.copy: Gov. Kate Brown paused Oregon's reopening efforts June 11, after the state saw the most single-day cases of coronavirus since the pandemic began. Brown had moved 26 of Oregon's 29 counties to phase two of reopening June 8. Restaurants and bars can stay open later and increase capacity with outdoor seating. Bowling alleys, swimming pools and movie theaters can also reopen. On May 18, a judge said that Gov. Kate Brown's emergency coronavirus restrictions violate state law and are “null and void." The state immediately filed an appeal with the Oregon Supreme Court.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 1,894 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 1,726 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: O, T, R, C, E, S
states.copy: Gov. Tom Wolf announced July 1 that masks are now mandatory "whenever anyone leaves home." All Pennsylvania counties are in Gov. Tom Wolf's "green phase" of reopening. most businesses are open, with capacity and safety guidelines. Residents can get their hair cut, eat in restaurants, belly up to the bar, work out in large gyms and see movies in a cinema. Schools could reopen beginning July 1.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 4,930 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 4,471 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: B, R, C, T, E, F
states.copy: Gov. Wanda Vázquez extended Puerto Rico's curfew for three weeks but authorized the reopening of certain businesses and government agencies. Puerto Rico reopened for inbound tourism starting July 15. Starting June 16, beaches, churches and businesses including movie theaters and gyms could reopen. Restaurants and casinos can operate at 75% capacity. Malls reopened on June 8. On May 11, Vázquez Garced allowed construction and manufacturing to resume, provided that strict measures are followed to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. Among the sectors included were private construction and maintenance and repair work done to bolster the infrastructure in anticipation of hurricane season.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 1,254 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 731 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: R, T, P, F, C, B, S, G
states.copy: Rhode Island's phase three of reopening began June 30, easing restrictions for indoor and outdoor social gatherings, reopening entertainment values with some guidelines and other milestones. Gov. Gina Raimondo ordered anyone arriving in Rhode Island from a state seeing a surge in new COVID cases to quarantine for 14 days unless they can show they recently tested negative for the disease. Schools can reopen August 31. Phase two expanded in-person dining options at restaurants from outdoor-only to indoor with limitations; allow gyms, hairdressers and nail salons to welcome back customers; let youth sports start up again; and reopen all state beaches. Raimondo allowed restaurants to offer limited outdoor dining starting May 18 under regulations from the governor’s office.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 302 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 301 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: T, R, C, F, E, S
states.copy: Guidelines for reopening South Carolna public schools were announced June 22. Bowling alleys in South Carolina could reopen June 12, and schools have the option to reopen in the fall. On the same day, Gov. Henry McMaster extended the state of emergency and lifted restrictions on retail stores capacity and allowed events with more than 50 people at state properties. In-person graduation ceremonies could take place beginning May 29. Close-contact businesses including gyms, barber shops, hair salons and pools reopened on May 18. On May 11, Gov. Henry McMaster allowed dining inside South Carolina restaurants to resume.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 10,990 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 10,679 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: T, H, O, F, E
states.copy: Gov. Kristi Noem unveiled a "Back to Normal Plan"  in late April for businesses and residents for the next phase of the coronavirus response. The plan lays out actions for residents, employers, schools and health care providers once four criteria categories are met, including a downward trajectory of documented coronavirus cases for 14 days in an area with sustained community spread.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 443 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 414 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: C, R, T, F, G, E
states.copy: As cases of coronavirus continue to soar in Tennessee, Gov. Bill Lee extended his state of emergency declaration on Monday, along with a host of other provisions that were set to expire. Tennessee will remain in a state of emergency until at least Aug. 29, according to Lee's latest order. Nashville entered phase three of reopening June 22. Restaurants and retail stores in Tennessee could reopen at 100% capacity starting May 22. The state reopened salons and barber shops May 6, the latest in a string of restrictions to be loosened in the state. Guidance issued by Lee's office May 1 says house of worship should exercise caution, encouraging their community members to wear face coverings and remain six feet away from others.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 10,701 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 8,856 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: T, O, R, E, C, F, S
states.copy: Gov. Greg Abbott on June 26 reinstituted restrictions to bars, rafting and tubing services and gatherings of more than 100 people, after a surge in coronavirus cases. Phase three of reopening Texas had started June 12, allowing restaurants to increase capacity to 75%. The phase began June 3, with 50% capacity restrictions. School districts could open for summer programming June 1. Child care facilities can reopen, and bars could open May 22 with limited capacity. Sporting events can return without fans beginning May 31. Hair and nail salons reopened May 8 with restrictions on capacity and distances and gyms got back to business on May 18, Abbott said.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 57,404 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 44,579 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: G, R, T, E
states.copy: A week after mandating masks at all state facilities, troubling numbers prompted Utah Gov. Gary Herbert to require masks in regions of Utah that are home to several of the state’s famous national parks July 2. He announced a pause in reopening in June. Most of the state moved to "yellow," or low-risk, May 16. A yellow designation means there can be social gatherings of up to 50 people, team sports are allowed and swimming pools are opened. Additionally, travel is opened up throughout the state — though Washington County has seen significant visitor numbers in recent weeks at the state parks.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 4,086 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 3,896 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: O, T, G, S, C, R, H
states.copy: Now that the Vermont Agency of Education has released its fall reopening guidelines, local schools and educators are undertaking the process of applying the policies to their programs. Gov. Phil Scott allowed indoor dining at restaurants and lift some travel restrictions June 8. On May 22, Scott announced the resumption of some business operations, including outdoor seating at restaurants and bars, hair salons and barber shops and some additional health services. Vermont's retail stores began reopening on May 18, with certain conditions. Big box stores were also allowed to begin selling non-essential items again. Child care programs and summer camps in will be allowed to open this summer — as long as they follow strict health guidelines to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. Gatherings of 10 people or fewer were allowed with precautions and golf courses and some other forms of outdoor recreation reopened May 7, Scott announced May 6.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 45 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 36 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: H, R, B, F, E, S
states.copy: Though Gov. Ralph Northam announced July 1 the state would begin its third phase of reopening, he has decided to prohibit bar seating. Phase three will affect, pools, salons, retail and other businesses. Northern Virginia entered phase two of reopening June 12, allowing more flexibility for restaurants, gyms, sports, and outdoor entertainment venues. Beaches were allowed to open May 29.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 4,253 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 3,789 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: O, T, H, E, R, G, P
states.copy: Days after Gov. Jay Inslee delayed phase four of reopening amid a surge in coronavirus cases, he announced a short-term extension to the state's "Safe Start" emergency guidelines through at least July 8. Twelve counties moved into phase three of reopening June 17, which allows restaurants, gyms, movie theaters and other businesses to open with capacity restrictions. Non-essential medical procedures and services could resume May 18. On May 11, Inslee outlined metrics that counties must reach before they are allowed to move through the state's phased "Safe Start" plan.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 4,430 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 3,784 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: C, R, T, H, E, F, S
states.copy: Nursing homes began allowing limited visitations if they met certain requirements beginning June 17. West Virginia schools will reopen in August with an untraditional schedule. Casinos and movie theaters could reopen June 5, and campgrounds reopened June 10. More businesses reopened, including restaurants with indoor seating, on May 21. Fitness centers, tanning salons, gymnasiums and recreation centers are able to resume operations in West Virginia, with limitations. On May 11 physical therapy centers and drive-in movie theaters were allowed to reopen. Justice has so far let hospitals resume elective procedures and allowed the reopening of small businesses, outdoor dining restaurants and barber shops.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 773 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 359 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: P, T
states.copy: Wisconsin on June 22 released guidelines for reopening schools this fall. The Wisconsin Supreme Court on May 13 struck down Gov. Tony Evers' order shutting down daily life, marking the first time a statewide order of its kind has been knocked down by a court of last resort. The ruling, for now, immediately throws out the administration's tool to control the disease for which there is no vaccine and comes at a time when Evers has already begun lifting some restrictions as the spread of the virus slows down for now.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is growing, with 4,170 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 3,511 the seven days prior.

states.eased_buckets: C, F, P, S, E, G, R
states.copy: Indoor gathering limits were increased June 10. The state allowed outdoor gatherings of up to 250 people beginning July 1. Starting June 15, indoor gatherings will be allowed, and schools can resume in-person instruction. Wyoming allowed people to dine in at restaurants, meet in bars and gather in larger numbers, Gov. Mark Gordon said May 13. Yellowstone and Grand Teton national parks also announced plans to begin reopening May 18. Previously, Wyoming eased some of its coronavirus restrictions May 1, with barbershops, gyms, nail salons and child care centers among the businesses that were allowed limited re-openings, Gordon said. Tesidents were allowed to camp at state parks as of May 15. Also on May 15, a strip club in Cheyenne, Wyoming, became one of the first in the country to reopen.
states.caseload_trend: The number of confirmed new cases is shrinking, with 219 for the seven days ending July 9 compared to 224 the seven days prior.
